key_behaviors: Uses ChatGPT and Claude on a weekly basis for personal tasks
Leverages AI to research and compare shopping options, especially cosmetics
Appreciates AI‑generated tables, summaries, and direct links to review sites
Uses follow‑up questions to refine AI output and correct hallucinations
Sets guardrails and has clear expectations before asking AI for information
Envisions AI handling routine scheduling and grocery ordering proactively
pain_points: Occasional hallucinations or “wrong path” answers that require extra prompting
Having to remember and manually schedule appointments at the last minute
Manual effort required to reorder groceries and confirm cart contents
Lack of proactive, automated integration with calendar and shopping apps
Awkwardness of text‑only AI interview format
trust_factors: Expectation that AI will sometimes hallucinate, which lowers impact on trust
Confidence when AI provides links to reputable review sites
Trust maintained by using guardrails and knowing the limits of the technology
desires: An AI assistant that automatically schedules appointments and makes phone calls without prompting
Proactive reminders and actions based on regular cadence (e.g., “schedule this before I think about it”)
Automatic grocery re‑ordering with a confirmation step before purchase
Seamless integration with personal calendar and grocery‑shopping app
More human‑like interaction for sensitive or nuanced conversations

verbatim_quotes.quote: I generally like the way that AI presents the information back to me. I can get a lot of information at once and receive table overviews, and I can keep asking follow‑up questions compared to doing Google searches.
I guess I have encountered a couple of hallucinations or things heading down the wrong path. But usually, I can correct it by prompting it with a few more questions.

I wouldn't say it impacts my trust very much, mostly because I expect there to be some hallucinations or wrong paths. I know this is not a perfect technology, and I think I roughly know what to expect from it.
On average, how much do you trust the results or suggestions you get from AI tools? 3 - Moderate trust

I would really love a personal AI assistant to schedule appointments for me, especially for things that I regularly need on my calendar. I want it to handle all those tasks, including the phone calls I don't want to make.

I'm generally very bad at remembering that I need to schedule appointments before they need to happen. They tend to be scheduled at the very last minute and therefore have to be pushed out further than I would like them to actually happen.

I could also think of it benefiting from grocery shopping. I do a lot of online grocery shopping, so having my regular cart being ordered, maybe just asking me if I'm ready to reorder and confirming with me what's in there before it goes and does the regular shopping.

It's definitely interesting being interviewed by an AI, not having a person to really chat with on the other end. However, it did give me more time to think about my answers without feeling like I was making a person wait.

Yeah, definitely the reading of text, but also, you know, when there is an in‑person element to interviewing, you can have a different vibe with a person. There's just something different about being able to connect with people personally and have that experience, I think.

I think it could really depend on the subject matter. For instance, if the interview subject is on something really sensitive, like a reorganization or any other delicate issue, you would want to take the time to show people that you are listening to them with a human touch rather than with AI.
verbatim_quotes.topic: human vs. AI for sensitive conversations

unique_insights: The participant reports no personal‑use limitations yet, using AI mainly for low‑stakes shopping decisions and accepting occasional hallucinations as normal. Their trust remains moderate because they set clear expectations and guardrails. The most compelling desire is for a truly proactive assistant that anticipates routine tasks (appointments, grocery orders) without prompting, highlighting a gap between current reactive AI tools and the user’s need for autonomous, schedule‑integrated assistance.
